oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Invasive plant benefits a native plant through plant-soil feedback but remains the superior competitor
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Buerdsell, Sherri L.
Milligan, Brook G.
Lehnhoff, Erik A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: aquatic science
invasive plant
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Plant soil feedback (PSF) occurs when a plant modifies soil biotic properties and those changes in turn influence plant growth, survival or reproduction. These feedback effects are not well understood as mechanisms for invasive plant species. <jats:italic>Eragrostis lehmanniana</jats:italic> is an invasive species that has extensively colonized the southwest US. To address how PSFs may affect <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> invasion and native <jats:italic>Bouteloua gracilis</jats:italic> growth, soil inoculant from four sites of known invasion age at the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch in Sonoita, AZ were used in a PSF greenhouse study, incorporating a replacement series design. The purpose of this research was to evaluate PSF conspecific and heterospecific effects and competition outcomes between the invasive <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> and a native forage grass, <jats:italic>Bouteloua gracilis</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>Eragrostis lehmanniana</jats:italic>PSFs were beneficial to <jats:italic>B. gracilis</jats:italic> if developed in previously invaded soil. Plant-soil feedback contributed to competitive suppression of <jats:italic>B. gracilis</jats:italic> only in the highest ratio of <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> to <jats:italic>B. gracilis</jats:italic>. Plant-soil feedback did not provide an advantage to <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> in competitive interactions with <jats:italic>B. gracilis</jats:italic> at low competition levels but were advantageous to <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> at the highest competition ratio, indicating a possible density-dependent effect. Despite being beneficial to <jats:italic>B. gracilis</jats:italic> under many conditions, <jats:italic>E. lehmanniana</jats:italic> was the superior competitor.</jats:p>
